nbaars:
A little bit that's one of the reasons it is outside the WebGoat. The idea is almost the same for Jetty and other web servers. It is just a class loader with a Tomcat specific loader class as a superclass. The class is just a couple of lines.
I tried other methods before but all of them failed because the jsp servlet caches the context class loader during startup so everything we load is not visible even if we replace the threads class loader.
We can supply those adapters as a library to be used inside the webserver.
--Nanne

. For the 7.1 release you can use the following command with the executable war:
java -jar .\webgoat-container-7.1-SNAPSHOT-war-exec.jar -httpPort=8081
(use the 7.1 executable jar in the above command if applicable)
This will start WebGoat on port 8081.
. During AppSec EU there was a discussing we should not use the 8080 port as a default because it is a well-known port which might interfere with other apps (like Burp, ZAP etc). 
. WebGoat now starts running on an embedded Tomcat server which will give the opportunity to change the server address and the port number.

docker run -p 8080:8080 -it -v /tmp/webgoat-data:/home/webgoat/.webgoat-v8.0.0.M14 webgoat/webgoat-8.0 /home/webgoat/start.sh
In this example /tmp/webgoat-data on the host will be mapped to /home/webgoat/.webgoat-v8.0.0.M14 in the container. This way the state of the database will be saved (/tmp/webgoat-data can be any directory on your host)

I will update this one to allow the dash.. Fixed with new release. WebGoat cannot reach WebWolf through localhost, there are two options:
1) Use our docker-compose.yml file from our repository: https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/blob/develop/docker-compose.yml 
2) Create a network, see below.
For 1 copy the file and run: docker-compose up
For 2:
docker network create webgoat_network
docker run -p 8080:8080 --net webgoat_network --name webgoat -e WEBWOLF_HOST=webwolf -it webgoat/webgoat-8.0 /home/webgoat/start.sh
docker run --net webgoat_network --name webwolf -e spring.datasource.url=jdbc:hsqldb:hsql://webgoat:9001/webgoat -it -p 9090:9090 webgoat/webwolf /home/webwolf/run.sh
This creates a network and the containers are able to find each other based on the container name

. @grssnbchr the '?' syntax in prepared statements can only be used for input parameters so you cannot use order by ? in a prepared statement. Because you cannot use this you have to use for example a string concatenation. Feeding the result to a prepared statement does not help in preventing the possible SQL injection though the order by. So the question points to the fact that using prepared statements might not always save you.
. No that's not possible, parameters can only be used where one would put a single value, for example a string or date or a numerical value.
For example you cannot: 
SELECT * FROM ? WHERE id = 'WebGoat'
SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY ?
etc. You can only use the ? for values.

. I completely agree on the long term. On the short term, I am still new to the code base of the application so I might have missed something obvious but here is my analysis of the possibilities at the moment.
The stage id's generated in LessonMenuService seems to not be unique for stages. The other possibly unique property is the link for a lesson. The link is a string consisting of some special chars and integers, for example #attack/152/900. Parsing this into a unique integer where what we really would like seems to be 152 and the prepend it somewhere seems messy to me.
There is also the cid on the category that could be used. It could be prepended to the lessonId and then concatenate the lessonId with the stageId. We need the lessonId since a category can have multiple stages with same "base id". The result would be something like this.
c88-Cross-SiteScriptingXSS
c88-LABDBCrossSiteScripting
c88-LABDBCrossSiteScripting-XSSStage1StoredXSS
I fint that prepending the category name  that is used as the catId would make the id's very long although they would have good semantics. 
Cross-SiteScriptingXSS
Cross-SiteScriptingXSS-LABDBCrossSiteScriptingXSS
Cross-SiteScriptingXSS-LABDBCrossSiteScriptingXSS-Stage1StoredXSS
I think I might be most fond of the catId - lessonId - stageId since it consistently uses what could be considered a parent id on the child.
The following commit uses simple concatenation to build the id's. If we do not like string building in this way a utility function could be created in GoatUtils instead with the delimiter defined as a constant or parameter.

. After some more debugging I have found the following:
- CrossSiteScripting class extends RandomLessonAdapter
- RandomLessonAdapter has a method setStage that recreates the database
- WebSession.update checks if the stage argument is precent on each request
- When the stage argument is passed in, WebSession.update calls setStage on the RLA.
- The stageargument is passed with every request in the GHF-form
- It seems LessonContentView.js adds the arguments to all forms in makeFormsAjax by setting the url option for the form to url: this.model.urlRoot
- Since the link to the xss-lesson stage 1 goes to #attack/279/900/1 the stage argument will be passed on for each request
Now; a few questions:
1. Is the stage argument supposed to be passed along for each request so the WebSession.update?
2. Can we remove the stage argument from the GHS requests?
3. Should another argument be added to indicate that a lesson is "ongoing" and then update WebSession.update?
4. Other?

. I'm looking at one of the if statements in CommandInjection.createContent.
if (
    (osName.indexOf("Windows") != -1 
        && (helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("netstat -a")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("dir")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ls")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ifconfig") 
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ipconfig")
        )
    )
    || (helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("netstat -a #")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("dir #")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ls #")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ls -l #")
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ifconfig #") 
            || helpFile.substring(index, helpFileLen).trim().toLowerCase().equals("ipconfig #")
    )
  )
{
    illegalCommand = false;
}
So if the user is running Windows, all the commands are valid. Even commands like ifconfig # and ls -l #.
If the user is not running Windows, the dir # command and ipconfig # are still valid although they are Windows commands. Is there some historic reason to why these commands are valid on other OS's?
Perhaps the easiest way forward would be to allow a mix of these commands no matter what OS the user is using. However, I think it would be more interesting for the user to actually see the output of their command so then they would have to be OS specific.

. Hmm, did this ever work on WebGoat 6 using HSQLDB?
Looking at http://www.hsqldb.org/doc/1.8/src/org/hsqldb/jdbc/jdbcCallableStatement.html it seems that the syntax should be {?= call...}.
Look at the docs for org.hsqldb.jdbc.jdbcConnection.nativeSQL they claim that HSQLDB is very sensitive to the whitespace in the statement from 1.7.2:

But to avoid a great deal of complexity, certain forms of input whitespace are currently not recognised. For instance, the driver handles "{?= call ...}" but not "{ ?= call ...} or "{? = call ...}" 

But it also says:

It is intended to implement a less strict handling of whitespace and proper processing of SQL comments at some point in the near future.

Anyway, I had a look at it and failed miserably. When using the recommended syntax it failed in the init methods of the prepared/callable statement classes.

. Been pondering this for a while now. Since the screen id's are generated "randomly" when the plugins are loaded, the id's would either have to be predefined or calculated from the plugin name if we would like them to stay consistent after reboots and across builds.
Instead of messing with the id's it could be possible to create some mapping between the plugin name and its screen id. Plugin names like db-sql-injection, command-injection and cross-site-scripting are easy to read and understand and would create readable URL's while keeping the id implementation intact.
I have not dug deeper into this, I'm sure it has its pro's and cons, so I would love to hear other thoughts and ideas.
. One issue with this that I had not thought of earlier is that it seems many lessons depend on the numeric id's. So adding user-friendly URL's might break some things in an naive approach and would add a lot of complexity with a more sophisticated approach. It would also make some hints and solutions outdated.
Simply loading the plugins in a single-threaded manner would not fix this either since adding new plugins would change the id for any plugin loaded after it.
Perhaps it would be enough to have stable links for each release and that links might change between releases (if new plugins are added). It would be a bit annoying though. Another solution could be for each plugin to hardcode an id.
What are your thoughts?
. While watching a presentation of the Lagom Java EE microservices framework they said that they were calculating port numbers based on the hash of the service name to enable autodeploy and autodiscovery. Perhaps this is not a bad option.
When loading for deterministic id's we could calculate a hash that would generate an int in the range we want based on the plugin name. To me it seems like an easy, testable and flexible fix that should not require any other updates to existing functionality.
So if you agree on this approach, which do you want as default? I would argue that deterministic id's would be the default. Most likely because I don't understand the need for them to be random.

. So it seems start.mvc is not really "the start". start.mvc gets sent the navigation link from Hammerhead. Hammerhead looks for the parameter start=true to load the correct link before sending it to start.mvc. Without the link the page will not be initialised properly since Backbone will not know which screen to load.
So: we can either link to /WebGoat/welcome.mvc from the logo, or we can link to /WebGoat/?start=true so that Hammerhead redirects us.
I think welcome.mvc seems like a good place and makes for a cleaner URL.

Offline Fast Attack Scenario:

Massive Cracking Array Scenario:
(Assuming one hundred trillion guesses per second)    1.21 hundred trillion centuries

            <scope>provided</scope>

If tag 7.0.1 then you should use version 7.0.1 instead.

zupzup:
I'd like to take this if that's ok. Hey,
I'd like to try myself at this if I may. I did some analysis in order to come up with an attack plan for this issue and came up with some questions, which would probably have to be answered before starting:
On plugins:
One issue which I already encountered somewhat in https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/issues/265 was that currently, plugins are not properly localized, as they only use the "plugin/i18n/WebGoatLabels.properties" file and not the other languages as seen here
So that probably needs fixing.
Moreover, the question how plugins are to be localized presents itself, as the labels from the webgoat-container and all the plugins are merged together, a name-clash between plugins or the container would lead to labels being overwritten.
I think namespacing would be a viable route here, either by convention (e.g.: people need to use the prefix "xy" for labels in plugin "xy") or automatically prefixing the labels of a plugin - but in the UI, people would need to use the correctly prefixed label anyways.
Another possibility would be to create a specific labels-map for each plugin, then the UI could use keys without prefixes, as long as it uses the correct labels-map and fall back to the webgoat-container labels.
On the UI side:
I guess it should suffice to create a LabelsModel which is used by Views that use labels. That LabelsModel would just use the LabelService on the backend (and probably cache the data somehow, because they don't change regularly).
One could create something like a LabelView to extend, but I think that would probably make things more complex that they need to be.
Am I thinking too simple here, or would this be an acceptable approach?
On labels in general:
I'm not quite sure what qualifies as a label to be localized. Is it just every piece of text in the whole application?
E.g.: Menu, User Controls, Everything within lessons...
And what about the login-page - it is kind of external to the whole Backbone app, so that would probably have to be localized another way, right?
That's it :) I think if these things are cleared up, the actual implementation shouldn't be a lot of trouble.. I can take a look - I think I know why this happens.. I can take a look at this.. The way the LabelService was implemented in https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/pull/289, endpoints wouldn't have to be extended - the UI would fetch the whole set of relevant labels and then do the replacement on the client..

IWriteThings:
I am using the standalone file. The one linked in the read me.
https://s3.amazonaws.com/webgoat-war/webgoat-container-7.0.1-war-exec.jar
. Rebuild WebGoat To Use A Different IP For VM
- [ ] Rebuild the war-exec
- [ ] Change the Tomcat settings
- [ ] Create the FAQ Instructions For Doing So
- [x] Request Change To Compiled System To Accept Different IP in arguments
Example
java - jar webgoat.exec.jar --port 1234 --bound-ip 10.0.1.15
I will get this done this weekend. Please leave this issue open in the meantime as I get this done. Thanks!
. Changing the port is fine but the big issue is the IP. Being able to specify a different IP is much more important for those of us using WebGoat in an educational setting.
Thank you for continuing to work on these issues!
.
mattrussell33:
Hi All,
It is still not clear on the actions needed to set an IP rather than using localhost. Using webgoat-container-7.1-exec which runs on the embedded tomcat server, but I do not see any options to change the server address or config to do so.
Anybody able to shed some light on this?
Cheers :)
. Hi Dviros, A quick workaround I found is to use iptables to route traffic from your desired interface to the localhost and port.
Below is an example if you have interface ens192 configured  with IP 10.1.0.1 listening on port 8181
iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -p tcp -d 10.1.0.1/24 --dport 8181 -j DNAT --to-destination 127.0.0.1:8080
sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.ens192.route_localnet=1
Hope this helps :). Hmmm, I'm don't use windows much TBH.
Deploying webgoat on a linux virtual machine using VirtualBox would be an option. A bit of a pain just to use WebGoat but will give you the flexibility to modify the IP.
Sorry I couldn't be much more help than that!
.

Any other idea?.
DarkHunterer:
There is a slash missing in the "webapps/WebGoat/plugin_extracted/plugin/ClientSideFilteringjsp/clientSideFiltering.jsp" string.
You can work it around by adding it before "jsp" so it should look like: 
webapps/WebGoat/plugin_extracted/plugin/ClientSideFiltering/jsp/clientSideFiltering.jsp
. I fixed it locally but lost it long time ago. There are some more similiar issues in several places that I didn't have time to report.
.

sohelero:
I was having exactly the same issue of not seeing the lessons. I tried out different things but nothing worked. Then I tried something very different and could make the lessons available at last. Please follow the steps:
1. Download the latest WebGoat release from https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/releases
2.  Run the command in the folder where you downloaded everything. Most probably your Download folder.
in Kali Linux, go to Download Folder and execute the following command:
root@kali:~Download# java -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.VERSION.jar [--server.port=8080] [--server.address=localhost]
Note: VERSION can be M21 or whatever you find to be the latest. So, the command will be 
java -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.M21.jar [--server.port=8080] [--server.address=localhost]
By default WebGoat starts on port 8080 with --server.port you can specify a different port. With server.address you can bind it to a different address (default localhost)

If you use Java 9 or higher you need to run WebGoat as follows:
java --add-modules java.xml.bind -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.M21.jar

Note: Make sure you change M21 to whatever version you downloaded. 

In order to check the version of Java, run the command
java -version

Hopefully it will work this time. All the best. If you need help, pls feel free to contact me. I wasted few hours on this silly thing but you can avoid it. :)
Sohel 
ero007@yahoo.com
347 272 7946
.

klebertiko:
Hi @honk3x 
I just did like this:
git clone https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat.git
git checkout develop
git checkout -b 7.1
git checkout tags/7.1
cd WebGoat
mvn clean compile install
git clone https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat-Lessons.git
cd WebGoat-Lessons
git checkout develop
mvn package
cp target/plugins/*.jar ../WebGoat/webgoat-container/src/main/webapp/plugin_lessons/
URL: http://localhost:8080/WebGoat
cd WebGoat
mvn -pl webgoat-container tomcat7:run-war
I hope it helps o/.

dcarosone:
Ok, this might actually be 2 issues:
Issue 1: A doc bug / majorly unclear README with respect to "legacy versions", current development, and current release.
I saw the note about 8.x major development, and legacy versions at the top of README.md. The "legacy versions" link goes to 6.x. I wanted 7.1 which was described as the current release.  The quickstart section further down the page has a URL calling itself 7.1, which is what I used. 
I also checked the release downloads for 7.1, but that does not have anything calling itself "standalone".
It turns out that in the wiki, there is an installation page for 7.1 which doesn't help much, but also a 'running webgoat' page  https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/wiki/Running-WebGoat that says to download webgoat-container-7.1-war-exec.jar. Well, there's a webgoat-container-7.1-exec.jar (no -war-) which is the correct thing.
So I think it would be hugely useful to:
 link to the 7.1 release and wiki page at the top of the readme, as or more prominently than the 'legacy' link, so people know where to go for the current release
 change the name of the s3 download link, and generally update the lower part of the readme, to refer to development versions rather than '7.1'
Issue 2. The standalone jar is broken, and misnamed, in the develop branch, because development..

l50:
Sure, if you're offline then it won't be able to pull the tgz file. In my case we're online but there is a proxy involved.. I can wget it from within the docker container:
docker start <container name> && docker exec -it <container name> /bin/bash
cd /tmp
wget http://fastdl.mongodb.org/linux/mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.2.2.tgz
mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.2.2.tgz.1               5%[====> *cut out, but you get the idea*. @nbaars that seems reasonable to me. Only problem then will be ensuring that if users need to use a new version, that it is kept up-to-date in subsequent releases.. @nbaars The tgz file?. @nbaars Something like this?
```
On docker engine host:
wget http://fastdl.mongodb.org/linux/mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.2.2.tgz
In Dockerfile:
...
COPY webgoat-server-8.0-SNAPSHOT.jar /home/webgoat/webgoat.jar
introduce change here:
COPY ./mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.2.2.tgz /home/webgoat/.embedmongo/linux/mongodb-linux-x86_64-3.2.2.tgz
...
```. Awesome, thanks for the quick turnaround!. This is following the instructions on http://localhost:8080/WebGoat/start.mvc#lesson/XXE.lesson/5 for reference.. Good deal, closing the issue..

grssnbchr:
I wouldn't shorten it. With sqlmap, it only takes some minutes to enumerate the whole database using a boolean-based blind attack. But I have to agree, being new to SQL injection, this lesson was quite hard for me - on the other hand, I learned a lot about automated SQLI testing with Burp Suite and sqlmap.. Absolutely, I recently filed an issue concerning this: https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/issues/503 @nbaars , any take on this?. But on the long run, you won't get far without automation, anyways. ;-) . But writing a script is fun! :-) My less-than-100-lines-python-script cracks the IP within 10 seconds. . See https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/issues/470#issuecomment-403952388
The task is hard, but you learn a lot. . I can confirm for webgoat-server-8.0.0.M21.jar.
Imho, the problem lies in https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/blob/f9e552f1cd9f73cb360d3361eb70964c0f5979a5/webgoat-lessons/sql-injection/src/main/java/org/owasp/webgoat/plugin/mitigation/SqlInjectionLesson12a.java#L36, where all servers are queried for the given IP; not just webgoat-prd. . Also, I have a question:  The attack description says that an ORDER BY clause can be used to circumvent prepared statements: Question: Does a prepared statement always prevent against an SQL injection? Answer: No it does not
However, it looks like in the code that queries the servers, no actual prepared statements are used: 
https://github.com/WebGoat/WebGoat/blob/f9e552f1cd9f73cb360d3361eb70964c0f5979a5/webgoat-lessons/sql-injection/src/main/java/org/owasp/webgoat/plugin/mitigation/Servers.java#L45
The query is wrapped by a prepared statement function call, but uses normal string concatenation imho.
Can someone explain this, or is this a bug?. Alright, but why can it only be used for "input parameters"? What do you mean by that? If I only allow column names (by using a whitelist, e.g.), couldn't I use a prepared statement with order by ? ?. That was fast, thanks! I'll test it asap..

act1vand0:
@nbaars 
IMHO, this exercise should be a much simpler blind SQLi that's achievable by someone who's learning SQLi. I believe that's the goal of WebGoat; to be a framework for learning basic (perhaps some medium) level stuff. Writing your own script or using sqlmap seems to be completely out of the scope of this exercise. 
As it stands today, this exercise is way too hard for someone learning the basics and may frustrate the students and/or make them waste a lot of time. Just my two cents. Cheers.. Just read HTTP basics.
Step 2: http://127.0.0.1:8080/WebGoat/start.mvc#lesson/HttpBasics.lesson/1
Enter your name and see how the server responds with the reversed version of it. Use a proxy to see the traffic. You only see the following in the POST request:
POST /WebGoat/HttpBasics/attack1 HTTP/1.1
Host: 127.0.0.1:8080
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:62.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/62.0
Accept: /
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: http://127.0.0.1:8080/WebGoat/start.mvc
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Length: 15
Cookie: JSESSIONID=07EAEABCFAD252D56272222992ABB12C
Connection: close
person=testname
Step 3: http://127.0.0.1:8080/WebGoat/start.mvc#lesson/HttpBasics.lesson/2
The question reads:  What type of HTTP command did WebGoat use for this lesson. A POST or a GET. It's using the past tense did use and therefore refers to the previous step (step 2), the one you already tried and captured in your proxy. When you look at the request, there's no magic number (as shown above).
It's not clear that you actually need to try the request on step 3 itself, with a dummy value for the magic number question, since you don't have it yet. It's confusing that you need to fail purposely in order to have a first chance to capture the magic number you need to correctly answer the question. 
I can think of two solutions:
1) Include the magic number in step 2, and leave everything else as is, XOR
2) Rename step 3 so that it's clear you need to try the request in step 3 in order to get the magic number.
I suggest option (1) above. I hope all this make sense, and can serve as a tiny contribution to this cool project. Cheers..

auooo:
don't change the method manually (by typing text "GET"), but use the combo box "method" in Zap Proxy and select "GET"

@tanskim , I have a question about this.  According to the RFC7230,
 section 3.3, it says clearly about message body:

The message body (if any) of an HTTP message is used to carry the
payload body of that request or response. The message body is
identical to the payload body unless a transfer coding has been
applied, as described in Section 3.3.1.
message-body = *OCTET
The rules for when a message body is allowed in a message differ for requests and responses.
The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field. Request message
framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
not define any use for a message body.

So why I can't just change the method manually to "GET", and pass the param "changeMe" in message body instead of using the combo box "method" in Zap Proxy and select "GET" ,which moves the param "changeMe" to the http URI Scheme. In my opion, the effects of these two ways are supposed to be the same.
Really bothers me a lot~:confused:.

zubcevic:
Pull request #562 has a fix for this. 你好，I have noticed the same issue when the OS is e.g. Windows. Then the start screen also has one strange set of characters in the middle of the content. This is resolved by forcing the file encoding at start of the JVM.
java -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.M24.jar
That might very well be the same root cause. Please try out and let us know.. if port 9090 is free, java -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.M24.jar --server.port=9090 should work. 
However, Spring Boot has a strange way of reading the command line parameters and you can only pass on 1 parameter in this way.
The alternative is: java -jar webgoat-server-8.0.0.M24.jar --spring.config.location=/tmp/application-webgoat.properties
Then you can override any or all of the properties. I had to do this for both WebGoat and WebWolf on a server where port 9001 was already in use.. Wow those are a lot of changes in one pull request.
I like the quiz option in the CIA triad lesson. I like the fact that you have added a lesson which you can do with just the developer tools. I tried both using Firefox and firefox developer tools. It worked fine. However,I do not see the updated progress for the developer tools lesson. That works fine for the CIA lesson.
For the rest:
- you changed sql-injection lessons, but not the test cases. So tests and CI builds will fail.
- you should also add unit tests for the newly added CIA and developer tools lessons
- perhaps split the pull request according to the desired changes. one for each new lesson and one for other changes.
. If you download Oracle JDK11 and it is on the command path. java -version should show version 11 and you can run the application.
If you want to run using Java 8 JDK/JRE you should build the sources from this repository, just disable the JDK 11 checks in two of the maven pom files. Then running on JDK 8 will also work.
So it is not really a WebGoat issue.
Please be aware that you perhaps need to skip the unit tests as mentioned in my pull request and also that running unit tests and on IBM Java will fail as well. Running the app on IBM JDK 8 is ok. Running on JDK 11 makes the billion laughs attack harder. http://127.0.0.1:8080/WebGoat
is the starting point. The context root is very important.
java -Dfile.ecoding=UTF-8 -jar webgoat-server-8...jar.

galian123:
I found the solution. 


Use <?xml version="1.0"?><!DOCTYPE my [<!ENTITY root SYSTEM "file:///C:/">]><comment><text>&root;</text></comment> instead of <?xml version="1.0"?><!DOCTYPE my [<!ENTITY root SYSTEM "file:///">]><comment><text>&root;</text></comment>
In brief, use "file:///C:/" instead of "file:///".
I use Webgoat in Windows. file:/// does NOT work in Windows and it works in Linux.
file:///C:/ works in Windows.


Make sure there is no file/folder name with Chinese characters in file:///C:/.


Hope this help you.
.
